Healing and time.<[silence:1200]> The fight against decay.<[silence:1200]>
The word "pharmacy" comes from Greek *pharmakon*, meaning both "remedy" and "poison"—a duality that defines medicine’s power to extend life or end it prematurely.<[silence:1200]

In 1928, Alexander Fleming noticed mold killing bacteria in a discarded petri dish.<[silence:1200]> This accidental observation led to penicillin, the first true antibiotic, which reduced death from bacterial infections by 75% within two decades.<[silence:1200]> By 1945, mass production cut wartime fatalities from infected wounds by half.<[silence:1200]> Today, antibiotics add 5–10 years to average lifespans in developed nations.<[silence:1200]

Vaccines work by exposing the body to weakened pathogens, training the immune system without full-blown illness.<[silence:1200]> Edward Jenner’s 1796 smallpox vaccine—using cowpox—was the first, eradicating a disease that had killed 300 million in the 20th century alone.<[silence:1200]> Modern mRNA vaccines, like those for COVID-19, use genetic blueprints to trigger immunity faster than traditional methods.<[silence:1200]

Public health measures double lifespans when combined with medicine.<[silence:1200]> Chlorinated water (1908) cut typhoid deaths by 90% in U.S. cities.<[silence:1200]> Sewage systems added 15 years to urban lifespans by 1950.<[silence:1200]> Today, CRISPR gene editing targets aging-related diseases by repairing DNA errors, while senolytic drugs clear "zombie cells" that accelerate tissue decay.<[silence:1200]

Caloric restriction. Rapamycin’s anti-aging trials. Telomere therapy.<[silence:1200]>
